Award.AwardTitle: Rational randomness: Search, sampling and exploration in children's causal learning.

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
How do young children learn so much about the world so quickly and accurately? And how can they learn so much when, at the same time, they often seem so irrational and unpredictable? The research in this proposal will help answer these questions by bringing together ideas from computer science with research on very young children. The basic idea is that young children learn in some of the same ways as the most powerful machine-learning programs. Both the children and the computers explore a wide range of more and less likely possibilities. Moreover, children may sometimes actually explore more widely than adults and so be smarter or at least more open-minded learners. Some of their apparently irrational play, like their wide-ranging pretend play, may really reflect powerful learning methods.

This work should have significant broader impact for educational practice. If we understand children's basic natural rational learning mechanisms we can use those mechanisms to help teach science more effectively. In particular, there are significant practical questions about how we can leverage children's spontaneous play to help them learn. Similarly, this research has impact for studies of developmental disabilities such as autism and mental retardation. There is reason to think that children with these syndromes may have particular difficulty with the kind of learning about possibilities that is facilitated by pretend play, and understanding that learning may help us understand and remedy these difficulties.

POR.DRECONTENT:
How do young children learn so much so quickly and easily? In particular, how do they develop everyday theories -- ideas about how people, animals and objects work? In this project we used computational ideas, particularly from the “probabilistic models” or Bayesian inference approach to try to answer these questions We completed and published several studies of children's causal learning within the framework of sampling and search in probabilistic models. One set of studies showed that ideas from computer science and machine learning about “sampling” could help to explain how children learn about cause and effect. Another set of studies looked at children's ability to infer abstract relational concepts, like “same’ and “different”, in a causal setting,and showed that children as young as 18 months old could learn and use these concepts.

A third set of studies showed that young children can actually outperform adults in inferring an unusual or unlikely causal hypothesis, in both social and physical settings. We found this counter-intuitive “kids better than adults” pattern when we gave the same causal learning problems to participants from 4 to adulthood. Rather than reflecting a continuous decline, however, there were abrupt changes at life history transitions, particularly the transition from preschool to school age, and during adolescence. On a physical causal learning task, school-aged children, from 6-11, were less flexible than preschoolers, and adolescents and adults were less flexible than school-aged children. However there were no differences between younger and older school-aged children or between adults and adolescents.  On a social causal inference task there was an inverted U curve. Adolescents and preschoolers were actually more flexible than either school-aged children or adults. We articulated a theoretical framework to explain these results integrating ideas from machine learning, neuroscience and "life history" theory in biology.

In a final set of studies, we began the first cross-cultural and cross SES study of causal inference in children and adults, including children in Headstart programs in Oakland and children and adults in both urban low-income Peru and most recently in a small-scale agricultural group in Amazonia. Children from low SES communities in Oakland and Peru show the same capacities for causal inference, including the ability to infer abstract causal principles, as children in middle-class US communities. Moreover, like the middle-class children they are better at inferring unlikely hypotheses than adults, including adults in Peru. The low SES U.S. children showed some difficulties that were related to executive function deficits, but this relation did not emerge for the low-income children in Peru.
